DOC.HEAD: Snow Squalls From New Cold Wave
DOC.TEXT: A new mass of cold air moved across the lower Great Lakes on Tuesday with snow, wind and dropping temperatures. The surge of cold air and wind was expected to produce wind chill effects of from 20 below to 35 below zero during the night over central New England. Snow fell across northern New England, over much of inland New York state, northeastern and western Pennsylvania, northeastern Ohio, eastern West Virginia, western Virginia, northwestern North Carolina, northern Indiana, lower Michigan, northeastern Wisconsin, eastern North Dakota, western and south-central Minnesota, and north-central Iowa. The heaviest snowfall during the six hours up to noon was 4 inches at Watertown, N.Y. For the first time in more than a week, the National Weather Service did not report any record low temperatures. And the temperature reached 33 degrees at the New Castle County Airport near Wilmington, Del., the first time the temperature there had been above freezing since the evening of Dec. 15. There was dense fog in some valleys of the West early Tuesday. Heavy fog over Puget Sound delayed takeoffs and landings at Sea-Tac Airport, which serves Seattle and Tacoma. Airport officials could not say immediately how many flights were diverted. Heavy fog at Salt Lake City had flights running about 2{ hours behind schedule during the night, with some incoming flights diverted to Idaho Falls, Idaho, and Las Vegas, Nev. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 21 degrees below zero at International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 5 degrees below zero at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 76 at Bergstrom Air Force Base at Austin, Texas.
